{{also|Kriegen}} ==German== ===Etymology=== From {{inh|de|gmh|kriegen|t=to war, to conquer property or land}}. [[verbalize|Verbalisation]] of {{m|de|Krieg|t=war}}. Cognate to {{cog|nl|krijgen}}. ===Pronunciation=== * {{a|Standard, Germany}} {{IPA|de|/ˈkriːɡən/|[ˈkʰʁ̞̊iːɡ(ə)n]|[ˈkʰʁ̞̊iːŋ̩]}} * {{a|Southern Germany}} {{IPA|de|/ˈkriəɡən/|[ˈkriɐɡ̊ɐn]|[kʁ̞̊iɛɡɐ(n)]}} * {{audio|de|De-kriegen.ogg|Audio}} * {{hyphenation|de|krie|gen}} * {{rhymes|de|iːɡən}} ===Verb=== {{de-verb-weak|kriegt|kriegte|gekriegt|h}} # {{lb|de|chiefly|colloquial}} to [[get]] # {{lb|de|chiefly|colloquial}} to [[catch]], to [[come down with]] # {{lb|de|dated|rare}} to [[war]] ====Usage notes==== * ''Kriegen'' is relatively infrequent in the formal standard language, which prefers {{m|de|bekommen}} or {{m|de|erhalten}} instead. However, ''kriegen'' is very frequent in colloquial German, where the verb often retains the vowel shortening that is occurring in local dialects in the second and third person singular of verbs. Thus, ''(du)'' {{m|de|kriegst}} is often pronounced {{IPAchar|/krɪ(ç)s(t)/|lang=de}}, ''(er)'' {{m|de|kriegt}} may be {{IPAchar|/krɪkt/|/krɪç(t)/|lang=de}}. These pronunciations are not used for the rare sense “to war”. ====Conjugation==== {{de-conj-weak|krieg|gekriegt|h}} ====Synonyms==== * {{l|de|bekommen}} * {{l|de|erhalten}} ====Derived terms==== {{der-top}} * {{l|de|abkriegen}} * {{l|de|einkriegen}} * {{l|de|hinkriegen}} {{der-mid}} * {{l|de|hochkriegen}} * {{l|de|unterkriegen}} {{der-bottom}} ---- ==German Low German== ===Etymology=== From {{inh|nds-de|gml|krîgen}}.
